utterances: I love what I do.
And not to have to raise $20 or $40 million and to work on the issues and fight for the people of New York state is a great privilege.
And I love what I'm doing.
One thing about what Mary just said, Mary from Syracuse, about entitlement and dynasties, there was this letter to the editor in the New York Times today.

It said, is it amusing that Andrew Cuomo, who owes his whole career to his dad, may not get the Senate seat of Hillary Rodham Clinton, who owes her whole career to her husband, because David Paterson, who owes his whole career to his dad, may give it to Caroline Kennedy, who owes her whole career to her dad.
A lot of dynasties there.
Who said that, Ken?
A letter to the editor of the New York Times today.
I think in the end, name identification can help getting you up at bat.
But then you have to prove that you can hit a home run.
How do you like that?

I never use baseball analogies, but I think that Caroline Kennedy is going to have to do a lot of moving around the state, talking to real people, and convincing them that she can be an effective advocate.
We're talking with Congresswoman Nita Lowey, a Democrat from New York, represents the 18th district in Rockland and Westchester counties.
Of course, Political Junkie Ken Rudin is with us here, as he is every Wednesday.
And you're listening to Talk of the Nation, from NPR News.
And let's get Anne on the line, and Anne's with us from Sandy, Utah.
Hi.
I happen to be a registered Republican, but I've voted for a number of Democrats in my day because I felt that they were more qualified.

And it really kind of is disappointing to me when I hear even people of the Democratic Party say that she's - one person said dynasty and unqualified or, I can't remember what the words, I remember the word dynasty.
It's, you know, how much has she learned just by association with the political people that her family has been with all of her life.
I mean, you've heard of learning at her mother's knee or her father's knee, the Thanksgiving Day tables that she's been around all her life.
All the things that she's learned just by being around the people that she's been around.
She's going to have to learn a lot.
She's going to have to prove herself.
But by people just (unintelligible) off before she's even gotten out there and said anything or done anything, I think that's wrong.
And the fact that they're just cutting her off right at the beginning, I think that's wrong.
And I'm Linda Wertheimer.
Anne makes a good point, though.
People do object that she is yet to pay her dues by running in any political election previously, as all these other candidates - all these other people we've mentioned has.
But congresswoman (unintelligible) worked long and hard and well behind the scenes for the schools in the city of New York.
And also, of course, for her father's library and many other causes.
Well, there are many senators who had careers outside of politics, either as lawyers or as doctors.
Some are effective, some are not so effective.
So as I said, I think what's really key here is she has to go to all the groups and talk to all the diverse population.
She has to go to the delis and the grocery stores and convince people that she is going to fight as hard as she can.
We're living in tough times.
People are really suffering.
Unemployment is going up.
More people are ending up on Medicaid than ever before.
And she has to convince people that's she's going to be a tough fighter for an economic recovery package, make sure that New York will be part of it.
And she has to convince people that she really understands their lives.
As I've said before, the bar room, the boardroom, the supermarket, the upper-income areas, the lower-income areas, this is a wonderful diverse state.

And she's going to have to do (unintelligible) listening tour and a talking tour to make sure that she convinces people that she understands them and has the power and the authority to really fight for them.
Until now, she's had a quiet presence.
Although as I understand it, she been effective in raising money for the New York City schools, but it takes a lot to be a senator, and she has a lot of work to do.
Congresswoman Lowey, thank you so much for your time today, and good luck to you.
It is always a pleasure to be with you.
Have a good day, bye.
You, too.
And I would like to thank our caller Anne from Sandy, Utah as well.
But Ken Rudin, she's right.
This is hardly the first dynastic follower in United States Senate.
Well, first of all, let's (unintelligible) drop by who's elected the president in 2000, George W.
Bush, there was a guy by the name of George Bush, who was president before that.
Right now, in Arkansas, Mark Pryor is the senator, (unintelligible) and David Pryor was the senator.
In Colorado, we just elected Mark Udall to the Senate.
And Tom Udall.
And Tom Udall in New Mexico, of course, sons of a congressman in Connecticut.
Chris Dodd, his father was a senator in Indiana.
Evan Bayh, his father Birch Bayh in Louisiana.
Mary Landrieu, who was the mayor of New Orleans.
New Hampshire, the two current Senators, Judd Gregg and John Sununu, their fathers both were governors.
Pennsylvania Bob Casey, his father was governor.
And Anne, who was just calling from Utah.
Bob Bennett is a senator from Utah.
His father, as you well remember Neal, was Wallace Bennett in the '60s.

And that - you get my point.
Ken Rudin is political editor here at NPR, no matter what he says.
And we're going to keep him here as the Political Junkie.
He'll join us again next week on Wednesday.
As always, Ken, thanks for your time today.
Thank, Neal.

jazz world photographer William Gottlieb.
With a remembrance, it's musician and DAY TO DAY contributor David Was.
You have almost certainly seen William Gottlieb's images of artists like Dizzy Gillespie and Duke Ellington, without knowing who snapped the shutter.
Beginning in 1939, Gottlieb's photographs accompanied his weekly jazz column Swing Sessions in the Washington Post.
He was paid to write the column, but got no compensation for the pictures.
That has changed considerably.

Gottlieb's images of jazz's most august figures now command premium prices among collectors, and are also available in a book called The Golden Age of Jazz, originally published in 1979, and now its 12th printing.
I had the opportunity to review that collection when it first came out, and noted that the hardboiled humor that seasoned in Gottlieb's anecdotes was worth the price of admission alone.
A few weeks later, I got a letter from Mr. Gottlieb, who said that of all the praise heaped on his work, mine pleased him the most for having noted the wit behind the lens.
Generous soul that he was, he asked me to pick out a few pictures from the book, and then sent me some beautiful prints.
His black and white images of the jazz life are without parallel.
Taken in nightclubs with bulky Rolleiflex and speed graphics cameras, you can almost hear the pop and feel the heat of the flashbulbs in every image.
(Soundbite of music)

Some of William Gottlieb's photos are as famous as the musicians themselves: Duke Ellington in front of a dressing room mirror at the Paramount Theater in 1946, pianist Thelonious Monk looking blissfully spaced out a year later at the Cradle of Bebop, Mitten's Playhouse in Manhattan, and a portrait of alto sax legend Charlie Parker, and a young Mile Davis on the bandstand of the Three Deuces.
The images are without romance, as hard-edged and flat as mug shots, which somehow befits the rough and tumble of a jazz life.
(Soundbite of music)
William Gottlieb left the jazz world in 1948, and began to produce educational filmstrips.
He also wrote and illustrated children's books, including the million-selling Laddie the Super Dog for Golden Books.
But he will be best remembered as the sharp-eyed witness to one of the most creative musical decades in American history.
(Soundbite of music)
Musician David Was on photographer William Gottlieb, who died this weekend at the age of 89.
After 37 years with one leader, Zimbabwe has a new president.
Emmerson Mnangagwa was sworn in today at a stadium in the capital Harare.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Not yet.

There does not yet seem to be a consensus in the Senate as there is in the House to essentially go along with the White House, go along with the administration with its particular version of how a military commission ought to operate.
And let's start with where there is agreement.

There's agreement that these detainees, who have been transferred to Guantanamo and others as well, are people who have probable cause to thought to be guilty of terrorism or something else that should be tried.
There really isn't a group of people saying they shouldn't be tried.
And there is agreement that we have the right to set up the rules for how we're going to do this, which really nobody else that could do it for us that we could still it a American process.
We could, of course, turn them over to some sort of international court and a lot of people in the world think that would be a good idea.
But there's really not much sentiment for that in Congress.
And there is also agreement that we should be able to bring forward the evidence that is most likely to convict them.
But then you start to have disagreements as you get into some of the details of how this is going to be handled.

And as you say, there are some influential senators - three of them, often referred to now as the trio - who keep saying look, this is not just about these 14 or right now 2006's suspects from overseas.

This is a process that will come back to haunt us, unless we do it in such a way that we would be willing to see our own military personnel subjected to similar procedures around the world in the future.
So they're trying to take a broader view.
And one of the big disputes is basically the rules of evidence.
Does the defendant get the right to hear all of the evidence that's presented against it?

Especially when in this particular case, much of that evidence may be classified, and which the federal government may not be, or the Bush administration, may not be willing to share with the defendant or in open court and may not even want to have summarized.
They would rather it only be brought out in a closed session.
And that has been essentially the key sticking point.
I think that it's safe to say that no issue is more important than that in the minds of the Senators Warren - Warner, rather, Graham and McCain.
That, I think, is the one thing they care most about, because they're afraid that would be used against American military personnel.
And remember, of course, Senator John McCain was himself a prisoner of war in Hanoi back in the 1960s and 1970s.
There are also disputes about the appeals process.

And again, this goes back to the Supreme Court decision, the proposed tribunals that the president had talked about early on where the appeal would go - if you were convicted -would go up the military chain of command to the secretary of defense and then on to the president of the United States, all within the Executive Branch.
Yes.

And I think they will come to an agreement on this, whether it should go into the civil courts essentially, into the Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, or whether it should go to the Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces.
I think that will not prove to be one of the issues that cannot be resolved between these three senators and the White House and the House.

But to set a little further the political table on this, if you will, the House where Duncan Hunter, the Chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, is very much on board with the administration, is going to - we're to see the Duncan Hunter version of this tomorrow, Wednesday.
And then they're probably going to bring that out and vote on it on the House floor as soon as next week.
So the House will be on board with the White House at that juncture, whereas the Senate, it's a little bit more unclear.
Though Warner/McCain/Graham bill will probably be brought out sometime in the mid part of this week - today, tomorrow - we'll see some version of that.

And they would very much like to have some kind of a committee action on that and the House - excuse me, in the Senate Armed Service Committee, which Warner chairs, and then bring that to the floor of the Senate.

But as you mentioned earlier, the Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, has already agreed to bring the White House version - matching up with the House - out on the floor on it's own without any kind of committee action and insist on a vote on that.
